text: How long do people usually wait before downloading and switching to the new Julia version? :-)

elements.text: How long do people usually wait before downloading and switching to the new Julia version? :-)

text: Some of us have been on the release candidates for a while, come join us ! :smile:

elements.text: Some of us have been on the release candidates for a while, come join us !

text: usually a week or two but I've had success with previous releases not waiting. 1,6 is kind of a big one though so I am going to resist the urge for at least a few days

elements.text: usually a week or two but I've had success with previous releases not waiting. 1,6 is kind of a big one though so I am going to resist the urge for at least a few days

text: I wish I could join the RC world, but dang I work in prod and am not allowed to do OSS contributions or even report errors at work without formal permission

elements.text: I wish I could join the RC world, but dang I work in prod and am not allowed to do OSS contributions or even report errors at work without formal permission

text: <@UTRAUNYDA> note that you don't need to switch. You can try the new one while still using the old

elements.text: note that you don't need to switch. You can try the new one while still using the old

text: for me: about 0 seconds to switch

elements.text: for me: about 0 seconds to switch

text: I force myself to wait on work machines for the actual release, but for personal stuff I always at least do all release candidates

elements.text: I force myself to wait on work machines for the actual release, but for personal stuff I always at least do all release candidates

text: about -couple of weeks

elements.text: about -couple of weeks

text: Try the new one while using the old? That sounds useful. How is that done? <@U0179G7FG4F>

elements.text: Try the new one while using the old? That sounds useful. How is that done?

text: Download both binaries, setup an alias for newjulia and oldjulia, call your code with both and see if all tests pass/it's faster

elements.text: Download both binaries, setup an alias for newjulia and oldjulia, call your code with both and see if all tests pass/it's faster

text: just download the new one and throw it somewhere. Julia doesn't need any special instalation, it's perfectly happy to run out of any random folder

elements.text: just download the new one and throw it somewhere. Julia doesn't need any special instalation, it's perfectly happy to run out of any random folder

text: I usually add some aliases to zsh for the different versions and it just works

elements.text: I usually add some aliases to zsh for the different versions and it just works

text: nothing stops you from hvaing multiple installed versions of Julia <@U0138UTB7A4> . We don't have that python pain where the libraries can bork each other

elements.text: nothing stops you from hvaing multiple installed versions of Julia
. We don't have that python pain where the libraries can bork each other

text: Ooh I see!! Thats cool. Did not know Julia didn't need to be installed somewhere special

elements.text: Ooh I see!! Thats cool. Did not know Julia didn't need to be installed somewhere special

text: julia itself is contained in the folder you download. the rest is in .julia IIRC

elements.text: julia itself is contained in the folder you download. the rest is in .julia IIRC

text: I'm used to imagining installing software as weaving itself and entrenching itself into the system. Its nice to know it can be compactly stashed away into a random folder

elements.text: I'm used to imagining installing software as weaving itself and entrenching itself into the system. Its nice to know it can be compactly stashed away into a random folder

text:
The way julia deals with reproducibility, environments and installations is kind of amazing.
Its so clean and simple

elements.text:
The way julia deals with reproducibility, environments and installations is kind of amazing.
Its so clean and simple

text: yeah <@U0138UTB7A4> that's understandable survival adaptations from eyars of toolchain abuse by python and the gang

elements.text: yeah
that's understandable survival adaptations from eyars of toolchain abuse by python and the gang

text: installing a package and it working/not breaking other things is always surprising

elements.text: installing a package and it working/not breaking other things is always surprising

text: In fairness, we have the luxury of having seen many other programming languages fail spectularly and be able to learn from that.

elements.text: In fairness, we have the luxury of having seen many other programming languages fail spectularly and be able to learn from that.

text: (Or rather, Stefan and the Pkg gang did. So credit to them.)

elements.text: (Or rather, Stefan and the Pkg gang did. So credit to them.)

text: it also took us 3 tries to get a system we were happy with.

elements.text: it also took us 3 tries to get a system we were happy with.

text: Check the Pkg3.jl Juliacon Baltimore talk <@U0138UTB7A4>, all the good sauce history is there

elements.text: Check the Pkg3.jl Juliacon Baltimore talk
, all the good sauce history is there

text: Makes it to hard to go back to Python dep Hell...

elements.text: Makes it to hard to go back to Python dep Hell...

text: All such super useful info!! Haha yes exactly years of survival with Python and other software. Now Julia is helping me heal and open up my soul and see how clean the experience can be. Now I'm trying to avoid Python as much as I can now lol
